    "patch": "@@ -31,7 +31,7 @@ IT Pros/DevOps workers | <li>Examples include IT admins for on-premises Active D\n Highly regulated workers | <li>Examples include US federal government workers subject to [Executive Order 14028](https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2022/02/17/us-government-sets-forth-zero-trust-architecture-strategy-and-requirements/) requirements, state and local government workers, or workers subject to specific security regulations<li>Typically have a 1:1 relationship with their devices, but have specific regulatory controls that must be met on those devices and for authentication<li>Mobile phones may not be allowed in secure areas<li>May access air-gapped environments without internet connectivity<li>May work on locked down devices with Bluetooth disabled\n \n \n-Microsoft recommends that you broadly deploy phishing-resistant passwordless authentication across your organization. Traditionally, information workers are the easiest user persona to begin with. Don't delay rollout of secure credentials for information workers while you resolve issues that affect IT Pros. Take the approach of \"*don’t let perfect be the enemy of good*\" and deploy secure credentials as much as possible. As more users sign in using phishing-resistant passwordless credentials, you reduce the attack surface of your environment.\n+Microsoft recommends that you broadly deploy phishing-resistant passwordless authentication across your organization. Traditionally, information workers are the easiest user persona to begin with. Don't delay rollout of secure credentials for information workers while you resolve issues that affect IT Pros. Take the approach of \"*don't let perfect be the enemy of good*\" and deploy secure credentials as much as possible. As more users sign in using phishing-resistant passwordless credentials, you reduce the attack surface of your environment.\n \n Microsoft recommends that you define your personas, and then place each persona into a Microsoft Entra ID group specifically for that user persona. These groups are used in later steps to [roll out credentials](~/identity/authentication/how-to-deploy-phishing-resistant-passwordless-authentication.md#drive-usage-of-phishing-resistant-credentials) to different types of users, and when you begin to [enforce the use of phishing-resistant passwordless credentials](~/identity/authentication/how-to-deploy-phishing-resistant-passwordless-authentication.md#enforce-phishing-resistant-methods-for-sign-in).\n \n@@ -80,7 +80,7 @@ Users should have at least two authentication methods registered. With another m\n \n ### Onboarding step 1: Identity verification\n \n-For remote users who haven't proven their identity, enterprise onboarding is a significant challenge. Without proper identity verification, an organization cannot be completely certain that they are onboarding the person that they intend to. Microsoft Entra Verified ID can provide high assurance identity verification. Organizations can work with an identity verification partner (IDV) to verify the identities of new remote users in the onboarding process. After processing a user’s government-issued ID, the IDV can provide a Verified ID that affirms the user's identity. The new user presents this identity-affirming Verified ID to the hiring organization to establish trust and confirm that the organization is onboarding the right person. Organizations can add Face Check with Microsoft Entra Verified ID which adds a facial matching layer to the verification, ensuring that the trusted user is presenting the identity-affirming Verified ID in that moment.\n+For remote users who haven't proven their identity, enterprise onboarding is a significant challenge. Without proper identity verification, an organization cannot be completely certain that they are onboarding the person that they intend to. Microsoft Entra Verified ID can provide high assurance identity verification. Organizations can work with an identity verification partner (IDV) to verify the identities of new remote users in the onboarding process. After processing a user's government-issued ID, the IDV can provide a Verified ID that affirms the user's identity. The new user presents this identity-affirming Verified ID to the hiring organization to establish trust and confirm that the organization is onboarding the right person. Organizations can add Face Check with Microsoft Entra Verified ID which adds a facial matching layer to the verification, ensuring that the trusted user is presenting the identity-affirming Verified ID in that moment.\n \n After verifying their identity through the proofing process, new hires are given a Temporary Access Pass (TAP) that they can use to bootstrap their first portable credential.\n \n@@ -103,9 +103,9 @@ To bootstrap existing users to phishing-resistant passwordless credentials, firs\n \n For new users or users without MFA, go through a process to issue users a Temporary Access Pass (TAP). You can issue a TAP the same way you give new users their first credential, or by using Microsoft Entra Verified ID integrations. Once users have a TAP, they're ready to bootstrap their first phishing-resistant credential.\n \n-It's important for the user’s first passwordless credential to be a portable credential that can be used to authenticate on other computing devices. For example, passkeys can be used to authenticate locally on an iOS phone, but they can also be used to authenticate on a Windows PC using a cross-device authentication flow. This cross-device capability allows that portable passkey to be used to bootstrap Windows Hello for Business on the Windows PC.\n+It's important for the user's first passwordless credential to be a portable credential that can be used to authenticate on other computing devices. For example, passkeys can be used to authenticate locally on an iOS phone, but they can also be used to authenticate on a Windows PC using a cross-device authentication flow. This cross-device capability allows that portable passkey to be used to bootstrap Windows Hello for Business on the Windows PC.\n \n-It's also important that each device the user regularly works on has a locally available credential to give the user the smoothest user experience possible. Locally available credentials reduce the time needed to authenticate because users don’t need to use multiple devices, and there are fewer steps. Using the TAP from Step 1 to register a portable credential that can bootstrap these other credentials enables the user to use phishing-resistant credentials natively across the many devices they may possess.\n+It's also important that each device the user regularly works on has a locally available credential to give the user the smoothest user experience possible. Locally available credentials reduce the time needed to authenticate because users don't need to use multiple devices, and there are fewer steps. Using the TAP from Step 1 to register a portable credential that can bootstrap these other credentials enables the user to use phishing-resistant credentials natively across the many devices they may possess.\n \n The following table lists recommendations for different personas:\n \n@@ -146,7 +146,7 @@ Use the following guidance to enable the recommended local credentials in your e\n Method | Guidance\n -------|---------\n Windows Hello for Business | <li>Microsoft recommends using the Cloud Kerberos Trust method to deploy Windows Hello for Business. For more information, see the [Cloud Kerberos trust deployment guide](/windows/security/identity-protection/hello-for-business/deploy/hybrid-cloud-kerberos-trust?tabs=intune). The Cloud Kerberos Trust method applies to any environment where users are synced from on-premises Active Directory to Microsoft Entra ID. It helps synced users on PCs that are either Microsoft Entra joined or Microsoft Entra hybrid joined.<li>Windows Hello for Business should only be used when each user on a PC is signing into that PC as themselves. It shouldn't be used on kiosk devices that use a shared user account.<li>Windows Hello for Business supports up to 10 users per device. For more information, see [Prepare users to provision and use Windows Hello for Business](/windows/security/identity-protection/hello-for-business/deploy/prepare-users).\n-Platform SSO Secure Enclave Key | <li>Platform SSO supports 3 different user authentication methods (Secure Enclave key, smart card, and password). Deploy the Secure Enclave key method to mirror your Windows Hello for Business on your Macs.<li>Platform SSO requires that Macs are enrolled in Mobile Device Management (MDM). For specific instructions for Intune, see [Configure Platform SSO for macOS devices in Microsoft Intune](/mem/intune/configuration/platform-sso-macos).<li>Refer to your MDM vendor’s documentation if you use another MDM service on your Macs.\n+Platform SSO Secure Enclave Key | <li>Platform SSO supports 3 different user authentication methods (Secure Enclave key, smart card, and password). Deploy the Secure Enclave key method to mirror your Windows Hello for Business on your Macs.<li>Platform SSO requires that Macs are enrolled in Mobile Device Management (MDM). For specific instructions for Intune, see [Configure Platform SSO for macOS devices in Microsoft Intune](/mem/intune/configuration/platform-sso-macos).<li>Refer to your MDM vendor's documentation if you use another MDM service on your Macs.\n Passkeys | <li>Microsoft recommends the same device registration option to bootstrap passkeys in Microsoft Authenticator (rather than the cross-device registration option). <li>Users use their TAP to sign into Microsoft Authenticator directly on their iOS or Android device.<li>Passkeys are disabled by default in Microsoft Entra ID, enable them in the Authentication methods policy. For more information, see [Enable passkeys in Microsoft Authenticator](how-to-enable-authenticator-passkey.md). <li>Register passkeys in Authenticator on Android or iOS devices.\n \n \n@@ -328,7 +328,7 @@ This section focuses on phase 4.\n \n :::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"media/how-to-deploy-phishing-resistant-passwordless-authentication/enforcement-phase.png\" alt-text=\"Diagram that highlights the enforcement phase of the deployment.\" lightbox=\"media/how-to-deploy-phishing-resistant-passwordless-authentication/enforcement-phase.png\":::\n \n-The final phase of a phishing-resistant passwordless deployment is enforcing the use of phishing-resistant credentials. The primary mechanism for doing this in Microsoft Entra ID is [Conditional Access authentication strengths](concept-authentication-strengths.md#authentication-strengths). Microsoft recommends you approach enforcement for each persona based on a user/device pair methodology. For example, an enforcement rollout could follow this pattern:\n+The final phase of a phishing-resistant passwordless deployment is enforcing the use of phishing-resistant credentials. The primary mechanism for doing this in Microsoft Entra ID is [Conditional Access authentication strengths](concept-authentication-strengths.md#built-in-and-custom-authentication-strengths). Microsoft recommends you approach enforcement for each persona based on a user/device pair methodology. For example, an enforcement rollout could follow this pattern:\n \n 1. Information workers on Windows and iOS\n 1. Information workers on macOS and Android\n@@ -371,13 +371,13 @@ Target each group with a specific Conditional Access policy. This approach helps\n \n Policy | Group name targeted in the policy | Policy – Device platform condition | Policy – Grant control\n -------|-----------------------------------|------------------------------------|-----------------------\n-1\t| Windows phishing-resistant passwordless ready users | Windows | Require authentication strength – Phishing-resistant MFA\n-2\t| macOS phishing-resistant passwordless ready users | macOS | Require authentication strength – Phishing-resistant MFA\n-3\t| iOS phishing-resistant passwordless ready users | iOS | Require authentication strength – Phishing-resistant MFA\n-4\t| Android phishing-resistant passwordless ready users | Android | Require authentication strength – Phishing-resistant MFA\n-5\t| Other phishing-resistant passwordless ready users | Any except Windows, macOS, iOS, or Android | Require authentication strength – Phishing-resistant MFA\n+1  | Windows phishing-resistant passwordless ready users | Windows | Require authentication strength – Phishing-resistant MFA\n+2  | macOS phishing-resistant passwordless ready users | macOS | Require authentication strength – Phishing-resistant MFA\n+3  | iOS phishing-resistant passwordless ready users | iOS | Require authentication strength – Phishing-resistant MFA\n+4  | Android phishing-resistant passwordless ready users | Android | Require authentication strength – Phishing-resistant MFA\n+5  | Other phishing-resistant passwordless ready users | Any except Windows, macOS, iOS, or Android | Require authentication strength – Phishing-resistant MFA\n \n-Add each user to each group as you determine whether their device and operating system is ready, or they don’t have a device of that type. At the end of the rollout, each user should be in one of the groups.\n+Add each user to each group as you determine whether their device and operating system is ready, or they don't have a device of that type.     "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0f5389ed1eba236cc37f76735cea94426c7508dc/docs%2Fidentity%2Fauthentication%2Ftroubleshoot-authentication-strengths.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fauthentication%2Ftroubleshoot-authentication-strengths.md?ref=0f5389ed1eba236cc37f76735cea94426c7508dc",
    "patch": "@@ -1,6 +1,6 @@\n ---\n-title: Troubleshoot Conditional Access authentication strength\n-description: Learn how to resolve errors when using Microsoft Entra Conditional Access authentication strength.\n+title: Troubleshoot Conditional Access Authentication Strengths\n+description: Learn how to resolve errors when you're using Microsoft Entra Conditional Access authentication strengths.\n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.subservice: authentication\n ms.topic: troubleshooting\n@@ -11,57 +11,57 @@ manager: dougeby\n ms.reviewer: inbarc\n ms.custom: sfi-image-nochange\n ---\n-# Troubleshoot Conditional Access authentication strength\n+# Troubleshoot Conditional Access authentication strengths\n \n-This topic covers errors you might see when you use Microsoft Entra Conditional Access authentication strength and how to resolve them.  \n+This article describes how to resolve problems that might happen when you use Microsoft Entra Conditional Access authentication strengths.\n \n-## A user is asked to sign in with another method, but they don't see a method they expect\n+## A user is asked to sign in with another method, but an expected method doesn't appear\n \n-<!---What could be a good example?--->\n+For sign-in, the authentication method needs to be:\n \n-For sign in, the authentication method needs to be:\n+- Registered for the user.\n+- Enabled by the policy for authentication methods.\n \n-- Registered for the user \n-- Enabled by the Authentication methods policy \n+For more information, see [How Conditional Access authentication strengths work](concept-authentication-strength-how-it-works.md).\n \n-For more information, see [How Conditional Access authentication strength works](concept-authentication-strength-how-it-works.md).\n+To verify that you can use a method:\n \n-To verify if a method can be used:\n+1. Check which authentication strength is required. Select **Security** > **Authentication methods** > **Authentication strengths**.\n \n-1. Check which authentication strength is required. Click **Security** > **Authentication methods** > **Authentication strengths**. \n-1. Check if the user is enabled for a required method:\n-   1. Check the Authentication methods policy to see if the user is enabled for any method required by the authentication strength. Click **Security** > **Authentication methods** > **Policies**.\n-   1. As needed, check if the tenant is enabled for any method required for the authentication strength. Click **Security** > **Multifactor Authentication** > **Additional cloud-based multifactor authentication settings**. \n-1. Check which authentication methods are registered for the user in the Authentication methods policy. Click **Users and groups** > *username* > **Authentication methods**. \n+1. Check the policy for authentication methods to see if the user is enabled for any method that the authentication strength requires. Select **Security** > **Authentication methods** > **Policies**.\n \n-If the user is registered for an enabled method that meets the authentication strength, they might need to use another method that isn't available after primary authentication, such as Windows Hello for Business. For more information, see [How each authentication method works](concept-authentication-methods.md#how-each-authentication-method-works). The user needs to restart the session, choose **Sign-in options** , and select a method required by the authentication strength.\n+1. As needed, check if the tenant is enabled for any method that the authentication strength requires. Select **Security** > **Multifactor Authentication** > **Additional cloud-based multifactor authentication settings**.\n \n-:::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/troubleshoot-authentication-strengths/choose-another-method.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of how to choose another sign-in method.\":::\n+1. Check which authentication methods are registered for the user in the policy for authentication methods. Select **Users and groups** > *username* > **Authentication methods**.\n+\n+If the user is registered for an enabled method that meets the authentication strength, the user might need to use another method that isn't available after primary authentication, such as Windows Hello for Business. For more information, see [How each authentication method works](concept-authentication-methods.md#how-each-authentication-method-works). The user needs to restart the session, select **Sign-in options**, and then select a method that the authentication strength requires.\n+\n+:::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/troubleshoot-authentication-strengths/choose-another-method.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the dialog for choosing another sign-in method.\":::\n \n ## A user can't access a resource\n \n-If an authentication strength requires a method that a user can’t use, the user is blocked from sign-in. To check which method is required by an authentication strength, and which method the user is registered and enabled to use, follow the steps in the [previous section](#a-user-is-asked-to-sign-in-with-another-method-but-they-dont-see-a-method-they-expect). \n+If an authentication strength requires a method that a user can't use, the user is blocked from signing in. To check which method an authentication strength requires, and which method the user is registered and enabled to use, follow the steps in the [previous section](#a-user-is-asked-to-sign-in-with-another-method-but-an-expected-method-doesnt-appear).\n+\n+## You need to check which authentication strength was enforced during sign-in\n \n-## How to check which authentication strength was enforced during sign-in\n-Use the **Sign-ins** log to find more information about the sign-in: \n+Use the **Sign-ins** log to find more information about the sign-in:\n \n-- Under the **Authentication details** tab, the **Requirement** column shows the name of the authentication strength policy.\n+- On the **Authentication Details** tab, the **Requirement** column shows the name of the authentication strength policy.\n \n-  :::image type=\"content\" source=\"./media/troubleshoot-authentication-strengths/sign-in-logs-authentication-details.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the authentication strength in the sign-in log.\":::\n+  :::image type=\"content\" source=\"./media/troubleshoot-authentication-strengths/sign-in-logs-authentication-details.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot that shows authentication strengths in a sign-in log.\":::\n \n-- Under the **Conditional Access** tab, you can see which Conditional Access policy was applied. Click the name of the policy, and look for **Grant controls** to see the authentication strength that was enforced. \n+- On the **Conditional Access** tab, you can see which Conditional Access policy was applied. Select the name of the policy, and look for **Grant Controls** to see the authentication strength that was enforced.\n \n-  :::image type=\"content\" source=\"./media/troubleshoot-authentication-strengths/sign-in-logs-control.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the authentication strength under Conditional Access Policy details in the sign-in log.\":::\n+  :::image type=\"content\" source=\"./media/troubleshoot-authentication-strengths/sign-in-logs-control.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot that shows an authentication strength under Conditional Access policy details in a sign-in log.\":::\n \n+## A user can't register a new method during sign-in\n \n-## A user can't register a new method during sign-in \n+Some methods can't be registered during sign-in, or they need more setup beyond the combined registration. For more information, see [Register passwordless authentication methods](concept-authentication-strength-how-it-works.md#registration-of-passwordless-authentication-methods).\n \n-Some methods can't be registered during sign-in, or they need more setup beyond the combined registration. For more information, see [Register passwordless authentication methods](concept-authentication-strength-how-it-works.md#register-passwordless-authentication-methods).\n- \n-:::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/troubleshoot-authentication-strengths/register.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of a sign-in error when they are unable to register the method.\"::: \n+:::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"./media/troubleshoot-authentication-strengths/register.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of a sign-in error when a user can't register a method.\":::\n \n-## Next steps\n+## Related content\n \n - [Built-in Conditional Access authentication strengths](concept-authentication-strengths.md)\n - [Custom Conditional Access authentication strengths](concept-authentication-strength-advanced-options.md)\n-- [How authentication strength works for external users](concept-authentication-strength-external-users.md)\n+- [How authentication strengths work for external users](concept-authentication-strength-external-users.md)"
  }
]. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary."}
ai_summary.Response: These commits refine the documentation around Microsoft Entra Conditional Access authentication strengths. The changes include updates to the title, description, and topic type for several articles, indicating a shift towards a more unified and structured presentation of this feature. Key areas of improvement involve clarifying the creation and management of custom authentication strengths, detailing advanced options for passkeys (FIDO2) and certificate-based authentication, and providing better guidance on how authentication strengths function, especially for external users and during sign-in evaluations. The updates also address troubleshooting scenarios and limitations, ensuring a more comprehensive and user-friendly experience for administrators.

changes.author: Anna Huff

Merge pull request #9988 from jenniferf-skc/ConfigureWorkdayTerm

Adding new article for configuring Workday Termination Lookahead query

{"role":"user","content":"The following is the commit files that have changed: [
  {
    "sha": "1f515e2c7cda22a140b665a5e4f09f22febbc0fe",
    "filename": "docs/identity/app-provisioning/configure-workday-termination-lookahead.md",
    "status": "added",
    "additions": 155,
    "deletions": 0,
    "changes": 155,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/36df14ab66d83b81cbef7eb9b65dd4a1e60f950f/docs%2Fidentity%2Fapp-provisioning%2Fconfigure-workday-termination-lookahead.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/36df14ab66d83b81cbef7eb9b65dd4a1e60f950f/docs%2Fidentity%2Fapp-provisioning%2Fconfigure-workday-termination-lookahead.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fapp-provisioning%2Fconfigure-workday-termination-lookahead.md?ref=36df14ab66d83b81cbef7eb9b65dd4a1e60f950f",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,155 @@\n+---\n+title: Configure Workday Termination Lookahead \n+description: Enable Termination Lookahead query for your Workday-to-AD/Microsoft Entra ID provisioning job.\n+author: jenniferf-skc\n+manager: pmwongera\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.subservice: app-provisioning\n+ms.topic: how-to\n+ms.date: 10/24/2025\n+ms.author: jfields\n+ms.reviewer: chmutali\n+ai-usage: ai-assisted\n+\n+#customer intent: As an IT admin, I want to understand how to enable the Workday Termination Lookahead query so I can leverage it for Workday-to-AD/Microsoft Entra ID provisioning.\n+---\n+\n+# Configure Workday termination lookahead (Preview)\n+\n+The Microsoft Entra Workday provisioning connector retrieves worker data using the Workday Integration System User (ISU) account via the `Get_Workers` SOAP API. However, the Workday ISU account always operates in the Pacific Time Zone (PT), causing delays in processing termination events for workers in time zones ahead of PT.\n+\n+For example, let's say a Workday user in **Melbourne (UTC+10, +17 hours ahead of PDT in May)** is terminated with an effective termination date of **May 14, 2025, 11:59 PM Melbourne time**. Using the Workday ISU account, the Microsoft Entra Workday connector fetches the termination event in the provisioning cycle that runs after **May 14, 2025, 11:59 PM PDT**, which is **May 15, 2025, 4:59 PM Melbourne time**—a significant delay.\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> We make public previews available to our customers under the terms applicable to previews. These terms are outlined in the overall Microsoft product terms for [online services](https://www.microsoft.com/licensing/terms/product/ForOnlineServices/all).\n+\n+To mitigate this issue, the connector now includes a **24-hour termination lookahead query**. This query ensures termination-related attributes (`StatusTerminationLastDayOfWork`, `StatusTerminationDate`) appear in the connector feed when the termination day begins in PT. The exact processing time varies due to daylight saving time adjustments.\n+\n+Examples of when termination details start appearing in the feed:\n+\n+- **Melbourne (UTC+10, PDT+17)** → May 14, 2025, **5:00 PM Melbourne time**\n+\n+For a user in Melbourne whose last working day is 14-May-2025, the connector starts including the attributes `StatusTerminationLastDayOfWork` and `StatusTerminationDate`, starting Melbourne time at 5:00pm on 14-May-2025, which corresponds to the 17-hour time difference between PDT and Melbourne time in May.\n+\n+- **India (IST, UTC+5:30, PDT+13.5)** → May 14, 2025, **1:30 PM India time**\n+\n+For a user in India whose last working day is 14-May-2025, the connector starts including the attributes `StatusTerminationLastDayOfWork` and `StatusTerminationDate`, starting India time 1:30pm on 14-May-2025, which corresponds to the 13.5-hour time difference between PDT and Indian Standard time in May.\n+\n+- **Japan (JST, UTC+9, PDT+16)** → May 14, 2025, **4:00 PM Japan time**\n+\n+For a user in Japan whose last working day is 14-May-2025, the connector starts including the attributes `StatusTerminationLastDayOfWork` and `StatusTerminationDate`, starting Japan time 4:00pm on 14-May-2025, which corresponds to the 16-hour time difference between PDT and Japan Standard time in May.\n+\n+This adjustment ensures the termination data is available earlier for workers in time zones ahead of Pacific Time. By updating attribute mapping rules in Microsoft Entra ID, you can then implement time-zone aware terminations.\n+\n+## Job configuration\n+\n+1. Go to your [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://aka.ms/EnableLastDayOfWork).         \n+   > [!IMPORTANT] \n+   > Test the configuration changes described in this document in your test environment, before enabling the configuration in your production setup.\n+   > [!NOTE] \n+   > This link includes a feature flag in the URL (`userProvisioningWorkdayLookaheadQueryForTerminations=true`) required to configure the lookahead query setting.\n+\n+1. Open your Workday-to-AD/Microsoft Entra ID provisioning job.\n+\n+1. If it's in a **Running** state, select **Stop provisioning** to first pause the job.\n+\n+1. Open the Provisioning blade, then click **Edit Configuration**.\n+\n+1. Expand **Settings**, then check the box for **Enable termination lookahead query**.\n+\n+   :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/configure-workday-termination-lookahead/enable-termination-lookahead-box.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the selection of Enabling the Termination lookahead query box.\":::\n+\n+5. Click **Save**.    \n+\n+6. Expand **Mappings** and open the attribute mapping page.\n+Depending on your provisioning job type, update the expression logic for the account status attribute. If your provisioning target is Microsoft Entra ID, follow steps in the next section. If your provisioning target is on-premises AD, follow steps in the section [Workday to AD job settings](#workday-to-ad-provisioning-job-settings).\n+\n+### Workday-to-Microsoft Entra ID Provisioning Job settings\n+\n+- If your Workday provisioning job target is **Entra ID**, then in the attribute mappings section, update the logic associated with `accountEnabled` flag to include a check for **Last Day of Work**.\n+\n+```python\n+Switch([StatusTerminationLastDayOfWork],   \n+  Switch([Active\\], \"True\",  \n+\"0\", \"False\",   \n+\"1\", IIF(DateDiff(\"d\", DateAdd(\"h\",\"9\",Now()),CDate(  \n+    Switch([StatusTerminationLastDayOfWork],[StatusTerminationLastDayOfWork],  \n+\"\",\"9999-12-31\")  \n+    )  \n+  ) <= 0, \"False\", \"True\")  \n+  ),  \n+\"\", Switch([Active], , \"1\", \"True\", \"0\", \"False\")  \n+)\n+```\n+\n+The expression checks for the presence of `StatusTerminationLastDayOfWork`, which is the attribute that is retrieved as part of the termination lookahead query.\n+\n+- If the attribute `StatusTerminationLastDayOfWork` is present and if the worker is inactive in Workday, then the Worker account is disabled in Microsoft Entra.\n+\n+- If the attribute `StatusTerminationLastDayOfWork` is present and if the worker is still active, then the DateDiff logic is triggered, which checks if `StatusTerminationLastDayOfWork` is today. In the DateAdd parameter, use the UTC offset corresponding to your region, so your date comparison logic returns the correct value. For example, if your region is Japan, then use the value **9**.\n+\n+- If the attribute `StatusTerminationLastDayOfWork` is missing, then it uses the default expression based on the **Active** flag associated with the user.\n+\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/configure-workday-termination-lookahead/edit-attribute-mapping.png\" alt-text=\"A screenshot of the Edit Attribute fields.\":::\n+\n+- If your Workday provisioning job target is **Entra ID**, you can also flow the `StatusTerminationLastDayOfWork` to the `employeeLeaveDateTime` attribute and then trigger Leaver Lifecycle Workflows based on the `employeeLeaveDateTime`. The advantage of this approach is that it'll always use the UTC time zone to trigger the account to disable the task. This saves you from using UTC offsets in expression mappings.\n+\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/configure-workday-termination-lookahead/entra-id-workday-attribute-mappings.png\" alt-text=\"A screenshot of Microsoft Entra ID and Workday attribute mappings.\" lightbox=\"media/configure-workday-termination-lookahead/entra-id-workday-attribute-mappings.png\":::\n+\n+- After changing any settings, make sure to save the provisioning job.\n+\n+### Workday-to-AD Provisioning Job settings\n+\n+- If your Workday provisioning job target is **Active Directory**, then in the attribute mappings section, update the logic associated with the `accountDisabled` flag to include a check for **Last Day of Work**.\n+\n+```python\n+Switch([StatusTerminationLastDayOfWork],   \n+  Switch([Active], \"False\",  \n+\"0\", \"True\",   \n+\"1\", IIF(DateDiff(\"d\", DateAdd(\"h\",\"9\",Now()),CDate(  \n+    Switch([StatusTerminationLastDayOfWork\\],[StatusTerminationLastDayOfWork],  \n+\"\",\"9999-12-31\")  \n+    )  \n+  ) <= 0, \"True\", \"False\")  \n+  ),  \n+\"\", Switch([Active], , \"1\", \"False\", \"0\", \"True\")  \n+)\n+```\n+\n+The expression checks for the presence of `StatusTerminationLastDayOfWork`, which is the attribute that is retrieved as part of the termination lookahead query.\n+\n+- If the attribute `StatusTerminationLastDayOfWork` is present and if the worker is inactive in Workday, then the Worker account is disabled in AD.\n+\n+- If the attribute `StatusTerminationLastDayOfWork` is present and if the worker is still active, then the DateDiff logic is triggered, which checks if `StatusTerminationLastDayOfWork` is today. In the DateAdd parameter, use the UTC offset corresponding to your region, so your date comparison logic returns the correct value. For example, if your region is Japan, then use the value **9**.\n+\n+- If the attribute `StatusTerminationLastDayOfWork` is missing, then it uses the default expression based on the **Active** flag associated with the user.\n+\n+- Optionally, you can configure the `accountExpires` attribute in on-premises AD to use this date. Use the expression mapping.\n+\n+`NumFromDate([StatusTerminationLastDayOfWork])`\n+\n+- Optionally, you can flow the last day of work to an extension attribute in on-premises AD.\n+\n+- After changing any settings, make sure to save the provisioning job.\n+\n+## Test your configuration\n+\n+### Terminate a worker in Workday\n+\n+In Workday, terminate a user and set the user’s termination date and last day of work to a date that is 24 hours into the future, using Pacific Time zone as reference.\n+\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/configure-workday-termination-lookahead/workday-worker-history.png\" alt-text=\"A screenshot of business process history of an employee.\" lightbox=\"media/configure-workday-termination-lookahead/workday-worker-history.png\":::\n+\n+For example, in the test scenario shown above, the terminated worker is in the Melbourne time zone and his last day of work is set to May 28, 2025 Melbourne time. If this was a usual provisioning job run (without the lookahead query), the connector wouldn't see this termination event until the end of day Pacific time on May 28, 2025, which corresponds to May 29, 2025 5pm Melbourne time. However, with lookahead query, you'll now see the change show up as early as May 28, 2025 5pm Melbourne time, so the connector can disable the account based on the expression mapping logic.\n+\n+### Run provision on demand for the worker\n+\n+With the lookahead query, the last day of work for the user was fetched and the `accountEnabled` flag was updated to **False**.\n+\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/configure-workday-termination-lookahead/modified-attributes.png\" alt-text=\"A screenshot showing modified attributes.\":::\n+\n+### Verify incremental sync performing termination lookahead\n+\n+- After confirming the configuration change works with \"provisioning on demand\", restart your provisioning job.  \n+- Allow the job to reach steady state. Once incremental sync starts, monitor the provisioning logs for future dated terminations effective over the next 24 hours. These termination events are processed as per the expression mapping logic configured in the job. \n+"
  },

ai_summary.Response: The commit introduces a new document, "Configure Workday termination lookahead (Preview)," which explains how to enable a 24-hour termination lookahead query for Workday-to-AD/Microsoft Entra ID provisioning. This feature aims to mitigate delays in processing termination events across different time zones by ensuring termination-related attributes are available earlier in the provisioning cycle. The commit also includes several image files and updates the table of contents to include the new documentation.

    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0f827112f19ec66c75c0d8aa01efb6571bc464ad/docs%2Farchitecture%2Fbackup-authentication-system.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Farchitecture%2Fbackup-authentication-system.md?ref=0f827112f19ec66c75c0d8aa01efb6571bc464ad",
    "patch": "@@ -72,6 +72,10 @@ Certain other types of policies don't support use of the backup authentication s\n - Use of the [authentication methods policy](~/identity/conditional-access/concept-conditional-access-grant.md#require-authentication-strength).\n - Use of [classic Conditional Access policies](~/identity/conditional-access/policy-migration-mfa.md).\n \n+### How does certificate revocation work in an outage? \n+\n+To enhance its resilience posture, the backup authentication system can't perform fresh revocation checks. Instead, it relies on the state of the certificate revocation list (CRL) check that's performed when the session was last backed up. If you need to revoke before this backup expires, you should explicitly revoke the session instead of waiting for the CRL.  \n+\n ## Workload identity resilience in the backup authentication system\n \n In addition to user authentication, the backup authentication system provides resilience for [managed identities](~/identity/managed-identities-azure-resources/overview.md) and other key Azure infrastructure by offering a regionally isolated authentication service that is redundantly layered with the primary authentication service. This system enables the infrastructure authentication within an Azure region to be resilient to issues that might occur in another region or within the larger Microsoft Entra service. This system complements Azure's cross-region architecture. Building your own applications using MI and following Azure's [best practices for resilience and availability]() ensures your applications are highly resilient. In addition to MI, this regionally resilient backup system protects key Azure infrastructure and services that keep the cloud functional."
  },
  {
    "sha": "d195efdec37a5b3d380c1262b54a1fa03c2846f0",
    "filename": "docs/security-copilot/conditional-access-agent-optimization.md",
    "status": "modified",
    "additions": 1,
    "deletions": 1,
    "changes": 2,

    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fsecurity-copilot%2Fconditional-access-agent-optimization.md?ref=0f827112f19ec66c75c0d8aa01efb6571bc464ad",
    "patch": "@@ -147,7 +147,7 @@ To configure notifications in the Conditional Access optimization agent settings\n \n 1. At the bottom of the main **Settings** page, select the **Save** button.\n \n-You can select up to 10 recipients to receive notifications. You can select a group to receive the notifications, but the membership of that group can't exceed 10 users. If you select a group that has fewer than 10 users but more are added later, the group no longer receives notifications. Similarly, the notifications can only be sent to five objects, such as a combination of individual users or groups.\n+You can select up to 10 recipients to receive notifications. You can select a group to receive the notifications, but the membership of that group can't exceed 10 users. If you select a group that has fewer than 10 users but more are added later, the group no longer receives notifications. Similarly, the notifications can only be sent to five objects, such as a combination of individual users or groups. To stop receiving notifications, remove your user object or the group you're included in from the recipient's list. \n \n At this time, the agent's communication is one direction, so you can receive notifications but can't respond to them in Microsoft Teams. To take action on a suggestion, select **Review suggestion** from the chat to open the Conditional Access optimization agent in the Microsoft Entra admin center.\n "
  }
]. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary."}
ai_summary.Response: This commit introduces a crucial clarification regarding certificate revocation within the backup authentication system. It explains that in an outage, the system relies on previous CRL checks and advises explicit session revocation for immediate effect if necessary. Additionally, a minor refinement has been made to the conditional access agent optimization documentation, clarifying the recipient limits for notifications.

ai_summary.Response: The document `docs/architecture/backup-authentication-system.md` has been updated. A minor edit was made to clarify how certificate revocation functions during an outage. The system now relies on the state of the last CRL check performed when a session was backed up, rather than performing fresh checks. If immediate revocation is required before a backup expires, users are advised to explicitly revoke the session.

ai_summary.Response:
This commit updates several Microsoft Entra ID documentation files. Key changes include:

*   Correcting a feature name from `EnforceCloudPasswordPolicyForPasswordSyncedUsers` to `CloudPasswordPolicyForPasswordSyncedUsersEnabled` in the password policy documentation.
*   Updating synchronization rule names in the SSPR writeback documentation.
*   Adding support for Windows Server 2025 to the conditional access conditions table.
*   Enhancing the plan application integration guide with new questions about policy inventory and expanding the list of user account locations.
*   Improving the govern and monitor tutorial by clarifying the prerequisites, changing "access" to "view" for logs, and adding references to Microsoft Entra ID Governance features.
*   Refining the "what is application management" article to include more integration methods and information on Microsoft Entra Private Access, as well as enhancing guidance on access management and lifecycle workflows.
